direct_answer.text: We simplify each term separately first. Recall that $\sec x = \frac{1}{\cos x}$, so \[\frac{\sec x}{\sin x} = \frac{1/\cos x}{\sin x} = \frac{1}{\sin x \cos x}.\]Next, note that \(\frac{\sin x}{\cos x} = \tan x\). Substituting into our original equation, we get \[ \frac{1}{\sin x \cos x} - \tan x.\]Using trig identities, since $\tan x = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}$, multiplying both numerator and denominator within the fractional part by $\cos x$, we obtain \[ \frac{1}{\sin x \cos x} - \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\cdot\frac{\cos x}{\cos x} = \frac{1}{\sin x \cos x} -\frac{\sin x \cos x}{\cos^2 x} .\]Factoring out common terms yields \[ \frac{\cos^2 x - \sin^2 x}{\sin x \cos x \cos^2 x },\]and using yet another identity $\cos^2 x - \sin^2 x = \

1.subquestion: Rewrite using trigonometric identities: \[\begin{aligned}\frac{\sec x}{\sin x} &= \frac{1}{\cos x} \cdot \frac{1}{\sin x} \\ &= \frac{1}{\cos x \sin x},\\ -\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}&=-(\tan x)\end{aligned}\] So our expression becomes \[\frac{1}{\cos x \sin x}-\tan x.\]

subanswer.text: To simplify further, let's write everything over a common denominator which would be $(\cos x \sin x)$. Then, rewrite as follows:\[\begin{aligned}\frac{1-\cos x \sin x \tan x } {\cos x \sin x }\end{aligned}\]Since $\tan x =\frac{\sin x}{\cos x}$, substitute inside numerator,\[\begin{aligned}\frac{1-\cos^{2}x \sin^{2}x /\cos x }{ \cos x \sin x} &=\frac{ \cos x (\cos ^{2}x \sin^{2}x )/ \cos x -\sin^{2}x } { \cos x \sin x}\\&=\frac{ \cos ^{2}x \sin^{2}x -\sin^{2}x }{ \cos x \sin x}\\&=\frac{ (1-\cos ^{2}x ) \sin^{2}x }{ \cos x \sin x}\\&=\frac{ \sin^{2}x \cdot\sin^{2}x/\cos x}{ \cos x \sin x}\\&= \sin x .\end{aligned}\]So our simplified form is $\sin x$. The answer is \(\sin x\). Note how helpful converting them back!

1.subquestion: Convert secant and sine functions using their trigonometric definitions (i.e., rewrite them as cosines or sines.)

subanswer.text: Using reciprocal identities where \( \sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} \) and simplifying yields \[\frac{\frac{1}{\cos x}}{\sin x} - \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\]. This becomes \[\frac{1}{\sin x \cos x} - \frac{\sin x}{\cos x}\].

ost_step.1: Combining terms over a common denominator results in \[-\frac{\cos x + \sin^{2} x}{\sin x \cos x}.\] Now apply Pythagorean identity \(\sin^{2}(\theta)=\cos^{2}(\theta)-1\) so it changes into \[-\frac{\cos x+\cos^{2}(x)-\cos^{-2}(x)}{\sin x \cos x}\] Finally simplify further as follows: \[-\frac{\cos x (\cos x+1)}{sin x \cos x}= -\left[ \frac{\cos x+1}{\sin x }\right]\] or simply \[-\csc x -1.\] Hence, our expression reduces to \[-\csc x -1.\]

subanswer.text: Consider the steps taken so far:\begin{align*}&\text{Start:} \\ &\frac{\sec x}{\sin x} -\frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \\ &= \frac{\sec x \cdot \cos x}{\sin x \cdot \cos x} -\frac{\sin^2x}{\cos x \cdot \sin x} \\ &=\frac{1}{\sin x} -\frac{\sin^2x}{\cos x \cdot \sin x}\\ &= \frac{1 - \sin^2 x}{\sin x \cdot \cos x}\\ &= \frac{\cos^2 x}{\sin x \cdot \cos x}\\ &= \frac{\cos x}{\sin x}\\ &= \cot x\\& \text{(Cancel Common Factors)}\end{align*}After applying relevant trigonometric identities and rules associated with differentiation at intermediate stages, what remains as a reduced form does match option C henceforth validated correct selection.<|end_of_document|> I'm sorry, but my response seems incomplete.
